articles.headline: Bluesky, Smiling at Me
articles.snippet: Bluesky has a hint of the old Twitter magic, but the feeling of freedom it offers might be even better.
articles.abstract: Bluesky has a hint of the old Twitter magic, but the feeling of freedom it offers might be even better.
articles.lead_paragraph: After an hour or so of scrolling through Bluesky the other night, I felt something I haven’t felt on social media in a long time: free.

articles.headline: Why Germany’s Economy, Once a Leader in Europe, Is Now in Crisis
articles.snippet: The country is facing a second year of zero growth, with industry leaders gloomy and worried about potential tariffs from President-elect Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: The country is facing a second year of zero growth, with industry leaders gloomy and worried about potential tariffs from President-elect Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Germans prepare for a snap election after the collapse of a fragile government coalition, one issue at the top of voters’ minds will be how the new government would revive the country’s once powerful economy at a time when energy prices are high and companies are cutting jobs.

articles.headline: Elon Musk Gets a Crash Course in How Trumpworld Works
articles.snippet: The world’s richest person, not known for his humility, is still learning the cutthroat courtier politics of Donald Trump’s inner circle — and his ultimate influence remains an open question.
articles.abstract: The world’s richest person, not known for his humility, is still learning the cutthroat courtier politics of Donald Trump’s inner circle — and his ultimate influence remains an open question.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the first 53 years of his life, Elon Musk barely spent any time with Donald J. Trump. Then, beginning on the night of Nov. 5, he spent basically no time without him.

articles.headline: Terms of Proposed Lebanon Cease-Fire Begin to Take Shape, Officials Say
articles.snippet: Key details still needed to be worked out between Israel and Hezbollah, and disagreements could scuttle or delay any deal, the officials said. But some cited reasons for cautious optimism.
articles.abstract: Key details still needed to be worked out between Israel and Hezbollah, and disagreements could scuttle or delay any deal, the officials said. But some cited reasons for cautious optimism.
articles.lead_paragraph: After weeks of deadly Israeli airstrikes in Lebanon and punishing combat between Israeli forces and the Hezbollah militant group, the contours of a potential cease-fire agreement appear to be taking shape, according to several regional and U.S. officials briefed on the ongoing diplomacy.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Isabel Kershner and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Emerging Details of Chinese Hack Leave U.S. Officials Increasingly Concerned
articles.snippet: Leaders of the big telecommunications companies were summoned to the White House to discuss strategies for overhauling the security of the nation’s telecommunications networks amid growing alarm at the scope of a Chinese hack.
articles.abstract: Leaders of the big telecommunications companies were summoned to the White House to discuss strategies for overhauling the security of the nation’s telecommunications networks amid growing alarm at the scope of a Chinese hack.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leaders of the top telecommunications companies were summoned to the White House on Friday to discuss a security problem that has been roiling the government: how to expel Chinese hackers from the deepest corners of the nation’s communications networks.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes, Devlin Barrett and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Cash, Kidnappings and Luxury Resorts: A Formula for Power in Modi’s India
articles.snippet: With a tactic known as “resort politics,” Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party has been accused of using brute force to take over Indian state governments.
articles.abstract: With a tactic known as “resort politics,” Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party has been accused of using brute force to take over Indian state governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: The lawmakers had finished a routine assembly vote and were scattering into the Mumbai night.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Atul Loke

articles.headline: As Threat of Trump Tariffs Looms, Europe’s Leaders Seek Greater Unity
articles.snippet: At a conference in Paris, corporate chiefs, finance ministers and top politicians called for a “Europe First” policy to counter Donald Trump’s protectionist agenda.
articles.abstract: At a conference in Paris, corporate chiefs, finance ministers and top politicians called for a “Europe First” policy to counter Donald Trump’s protectionist agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, European business leaders have watched as Donald J. Trump paved a path back to the White House by doubling down on an “America First” economic policy, putting protectionism and business-friendly tax and regulatory pledges high on the agenda.

articles.headline: Trump’s Trade Agenda Could Benefit Friends and Punish Rivals
articles.snippet: Donald Trump has a record of pardoning favored companies from tariffs. Companies are once again lining up to try to influence him.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump has a record of pardoning favored companies from tariffs. Companies are once again lining up to try to influence him.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sweeping tariffs that President-elect Donald J. Trump imposed in his first term on foreign metals, machinery, clothing and other products were intended to have maximum impact around the world. They sought to shutter foreign factories, rework international supply chains and force companies to make big investments in the United States.

articles.headline: They Investigated Pandemic Fraud, Then Earned Thousands
articles.snippet: Some private citizens are hunting for potential cases of fraud tied to small-business loans. They have earned big payouts — in some cases, more than $1 million.
articles.abstract: Some private citizens are hunting for potential cases of fraud tied to small-business loans. They have earned big payouts — in some cases, more than $1 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: When J. Bryan Quesenberry first learned that the federal government was sending out hundreds of billions of dollars to help businesses survive during the Covid-19 pandemic, he thought: “There’s going to be fraud here. There just has to be.”

articles.headline: Republicans Ponder: What if the Trump Tax Cuts Cost Nothing?
articles.snippet: Some in the party are considering alternative ways of assessing the federal budget as they prepare to extend temporary tax cuts passed in 2017.
articles.abstract: Some in the party are considering alternative ways of assessing the federal budget as they prepare to extend temporary tax cuts passed in 2017.
articles.lead_paragraph: What counts as a tax cut?

articles.headline: Trump Won More of New York’s Votes. Did He Win More of Its Love, Too?
articles.snippet: The city tolerated Donald J. Trump, and then it loathed him. Now, some New Yorkers have begun to embrace him. The Kid from Queens couldn’t be happier.
articles.abstract: The city tolerated Donald J. Trump, and then it loathed him. Now, some New Yorkers have begun to embrace him. The Kid from Queens couldn’t be happier.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even though Donald J. Trump is cloistered in Florida and planning his return to Washington, it seems like he has been stuck in a New York state of mind.

articles.headline: Should You Still Learn to Code in an A.I. World?
articles.snippet: Coding boot camps once looked like the golden ticket to an economically secure future. But as that promise fades, what should you do? Keep learning, until further notice.
articles.abstract: Coding boot camps once looked like the golden ticket to an economically secure future. But as that promise fades, what should you do? Keep learning, until further notice.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Florencio Rendon was laid off from his third construction job in three years, he said, “it was the straw that broke the camel’s back.”

articles.headline: ‘Wicked’ and ‘Gladiator II’ Jump-Start the Box Office, but at a Cost
articles.snippet: Battling a 27 percent decline in domestic ticket sales compared with before the pandemic, studios left no marketing drum unthumped in releasing the movies.
articles.abstract: Battling a 27 percent decline in domestic ticket sales compared with before the pandemic, studios left no marketing drum unthumped in releasing the movies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hollywood was back this weekend to where it desperately hungers to be — at the center of global culture.

articles.headline: How Southwest Airlines Lost Its Groove
articles.snippet: For decades, the company made money even as other airlines stumbled and went bankrupt. But the carrier has struggled to adapt to changes in air travel.
articles.abstract: For decades, the company made money even as other airlines stumbled and went bankrupt. But the carrier has struggled to adapt to changes in air travel.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Southwest Airlines started flying out of Bellingham, Wash., a growing city near the Canadian border, aiming to do what it had done in dozens of smaller airports — sell lots of tickets to people who have few other travel options.

articles.headline: The Amsterdam Attacks and the Long Shadow of ‘Pogroms’
articles.snippet: Many have used an old word to refer to recent events. Is it accurate?
articles.abstract: Many have used an old word to refer to recent events. Is it accurate?
articles.lead_paragraph: Femke Halsema, the mayor of Amsterdam, may have touched off a diplomatic incident last week when she said on a Dutch television show that she regretted having used the word “pogrom” the day after attacks on Israelis in her city surrounding a soccer match.

articles.headline: Immigrants Across U.S. Rush to Prepare for Trump Crackdown
articles.snippet: Donald Trump’s promise to carry out mass deportations has driven fearful immigrants to seek protections and advice.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump’s promise to carry out mass deportations has driven fearful immigrants to seek protections and advice.
articles.lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has vowed to slash immigration — both legal and illegal — and ramp up deportations on Day 1.

articles.headline: Trump Is Running His Transition Team on Secret Money
articles.snippet: Breaking with past practice, President-elect Donald J. Trump has not agreed to disclose the donors paying for his planning effort or to limit their contributions.
articles.abstract: Breaking with past practice, President-elect Donald J. Trump has not agreed to disclose the donors paying for his planning effort or to limit their contributions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated Nov. 27: Since this article was published, an aide to President-elect Donald J. Trump said that although Mr. Trump’s transition did not plan to sign an agreement with the General Services Administration, it would not accept donations from foreigners and would disclose donors’ names. The aide did not say when Mr. Trump would release those names or if he would limit the size of donations to $5,000, as previous president-elects have.
articles.byline: By Ken Bensinger and David A. Fahrenthold

articles.headline: How Universities Cracked Down on Pro-Palestinian Activism
articles.snippet: Stricter rules and punishments over campus protests seem to be working. Universities have seen just under 950 protest events this semester, compared with 3,000 in the spring.
articles.abstract: Stricter rules and punishments over campus protests seem to be working. Universities have seen just under 950 protest events this semester, compared with 3,000 in the spring.
articles.lead_paragraph: Colleges and universities have tightened rules around protests, locked campus gates and handed down stricter punishments after the disruptions of pro-Palestinian demonstrations and encampments last spring.

articles.headline: How Trump Could Upend Electric Car Sales
articles.snippet: Fewer people will be able to afford electric cars and trucks if President-elect Donald J. Trump and Republicans in Congress eliminate a $7,500 federal tax credit.
articles.abstract: Fewer people will be able to afford electric cars and trucks if President-elect Donald J. Trump and Republicans in Congress eliminate a $7,500 federal tax credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many car buyers have come to rely on a $7,500 federal tax credit on electric vehicles to soften the blow of their high prices. But those credits could disappear after President-elect Donald J. Trump takes office, leading to an almost immediate drop in sales of the cars and trucks.

articles.headline: Netanyahu Signals Openness to Cease-Fire With Hezbollah, Officials Say
articles.snippet: The United States is pushing Israel to reach a deal with the Lebanese militia by Thanksgiving, even as key details remained unresolved, Israeli officials said.
articles.abstract: The United States is pushing Israel to reach a deal with the Lebanese militia by Thanksgiving, even as key details remained unresolved, Israeli officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has indicated he is open to a cease-fire in the yearlong conflict with Hezbollah, as U.S. officials pressured him to finalize a deal before Thanksgiving, according to two Israeli officials briefed on his thinking.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Jack Nicas

articles.headline: Can Wall Street Billionaires Deliver on Trump’s Blue-Collar Promise?
articles.snippet: The president-elect has named wealthy financiers for key economic positions, raising questions about how much they will follow through on promises to help the working class.
articles.abstract: The president-elect has named wealthy financiers for key economic positions, raising questions about how much they will follow through on promises to help the working class.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump first ran for the White House in 2016, his closing campaign advertisement lamented the influence of Wall Street in Washington, flashing ominous images of big banks and the billionaire liberal philanthropist George Soros.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson
